message: I really enjoyed the first one, I'm staying cautiously optimistic for the new one. Looking good so far.

This GiantBomb video has about 10 minutes of gameplay footage: http://www.giantbomb.com/ask-me-anything-alice-madness-returns/17-3984/ Note the hair and dress movement -- these guys are accomplishing some pretty impressive stuff with Unreal Engine 3!
This is out next month, and looks really promising. I'll probably grab this Day One.

Launch trailer: http://www.gametrailers.com/video/e3-2011-alice-madness/714526

Hmm, early murmurings from reviewers seem quite negative. :(
The first Alice was pretty good for the time. A minor cult classic.
I find it odd that McGee remains one of the VERY few designers whose name is still gets banner treatment in this day and age… when he has done… what?

So the game in the US comes out on 14 June ie tomorrow and still no reviews from any of the big outlets? And it's from the guy who made Bad Day: LA? Somehow, I suspect this isn't going to be pretty....
Yes, sure, in 2000.  It still seems out of all proportion to me.

To somewhat answer my own question:  I think we forget the massively high esteem in which Id was at one time held.  They were the Beatles of (PC) game development.  So obviously there was a great deal of interest in the solo projects of one-time Id staff.

And in that context (to continue the fraught analogy), it turned out McGee was… if not Paul McCartney, then at least George Harrison.  And Romero was more like Ringo Starr.
Reckon I short-changed the bloke a bit.
Reviews are starting to come in: http://xbox360.ign.com/articles/117/1175768p1.html

So, I started playing this yesterday. So far, it seems to be an old-fashioned platformer with Zelda-ish combat. Nothing too ambitious here, but I'm constantly eager to see what the visually imaginative world will show me next. It's one of those games that shakes off the Unreal Engine look.

On Saturday I was starting the necessary paperwork to institute the Official Alice: Madness Returns Defence Force, but having played further even I have to admit that individual sections drag on for far too long. Still, I think it's a solid, enjoyable game that might not be particularly great, but is a hell of a lot better than the "mediocre" that Eurogamer or Edge would have us believe.

I finished this on Saturday. I quite enjoyed it. Yes, it could've probably been cut back quite a bit, but overall the platforming was fun, the combat was meaty enough and they kept on mixing the environments so you always had something new to look at. The artists really did have the most say in this game I would say.
